importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update, indicating recent developments in U.S.-Ukraine-Russia diplomatic dynamics, particularly regarding the potential deployment of Tomahawk missiles.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period since mid-2025 when U.S. President Donald Trump has been considering sending Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine, following a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Alaska two months prior.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump did not rule out sending Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine during a call with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Trump did not commit to providing the missiles during a planned meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at the White House, though the possibility remains open.
The U.S. administration has prepared plans to deploy the weapons if Trump decides to do so, emphasizing his authority to act at any time.
Ukrainian leaders view the Tomahawk missiles as a potential game-changer that could pressure Putin to negotiate a peace deal.
Putin opposed the idea, arguing that the missiles could damage the U.S.-Russia relationship and threaten major Russian cities, though he acknowledged their strategic value in terms of leverage.
Trump reportedly said during a phone call with Putin: 'Would you mind if I gave a couple thousand Tomahawks to your opposition?' — indicating a deliberate use of threat as leverage.

The threat of sending Tomahawk missiles is framed by U.S. officials as a diplomatic tool to pressure Russia into peace negotiations, especially in light of Trump’s broader diplomatic success in the Middle East.
There remains uncertainty about whether recent developments, such as the planned meeting in Budapest, would influence the trajectory of peace negotiations or change the threat posture.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the central decision-maker regarding the possibility of sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine, and his statements and actions during meetings with both Putin and Zelensky directly shape the article’s narrative.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is directly involved in the diplomatic back-and-forth with Trump over the missile threat, and his objections to the idea show the geopolitical risk and sensitivity of the issue.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky and his aides have expressed strong interest in receiving Tomahawk missiles as a strategic tool to pressure Russia into negotiations, making him a key stakeholder in the potential use of these weapons.

namedEntities.name: Tomahawk cruise missiles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These missiles represent a pivotal military option with the potential to shift the balance of power in the Ukraine war, and their potential deployment is at the heart of the diplomatic tension between the U.S. and Russia.

namedEntities.name: Budapest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Planned meeting between Trump and Putin in Budapest suggests a potential diplomatic pivot, possibly to de-escalate tensions or negotiate a peace agreement after Putin's intervention.

namedEntities.name: Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump and Putin previously met in Alaska two months prior to this report, setting the stage for the current diplomatic developments and ongoing tensions over missile deployment.

namedEntities.name: Middle East negotiations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s success in Middle East diplomacy is cited as context for his shift toward diplomatic solutions in Ukraine, reinforcing the idea that the missile threat is part of a broader strategy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has not ruled out sending long-range Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine, even after a recent call with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who strongly opposed the idea. While Trump did not commit to providing the weapons during his planned meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, U.S. officials have prepared plans in case he decides to act. Ukrainian leaders see the missiles as a potential game-changer to pressure Russia into peace negotiations, while Putin argues that they could damage the U.S.-Russia relationship and threaten major cities. The threat is framed as a diplomatic leverage tool, not a direct escalation, and the possibility remains open as Trump continues to pursue a peace strategy, possibly influenced by recent diplomatic successes in the Middle East and a planned meeting in Budapest between Trump and Putin.
title: Trump hasn’t closed the door on sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine
